text:

A teenage girl who was cruelly called "It" by classmates after being born a boy has inspired the first transgender doll. 
Jazz Jennings was diagnosed with gender identity disorder at the age of just three and began living as a girl full-time two years later following tests and counselling. 
The teen, one of the youngest people known to have transitioned, published her memoirs last year and has been praised for helping to shape attitudes towards transgender people. 
The 16-year-old has been named as one of Time magazine's 25 most influential teens, starred in her own reality TV show, and has now been celebrated by the Tonner Doll Company. 
The manufacturer, which specialises in adult collectibles and high fashion dolls, is to release a Jazz Jennings doll designed by founder Robert Tonner. When Jeanette and Gregs son was just two years old he asked when the fairy was coming to make him into a girl. He was diagnosed with gender identity disorder when he was three and started dressing as a girl full time from the age of four (Photo: PA Real Life Features) 
The doll will come in pink shirt and jean shorts, mirroring the outfit worn by Jazz on the cover of her memoir, Being Jazz: My Life as a (Transgender) Teen. 
Tonner said: "Jazz stands for everything I respect from a human nature point of view. She's incredibly brave, intelligent, warm-hearted and creative." 
It was unveiled at the New York Toy Fair at the weekend ahead of its release in July and will be marketed to children rather than as an adult collectible. Read More Coronation Street star Julie Hesmondhalgh says it would be 'wrong' for her to still be playing transgender Hayley The doll's creator praised Jazz as "incredibly brave, intelligent, warm-hearted and creative" (Photo: Instagram/jazzjennings) 
Posting on Instagram, Jazz said: "I hope that it can place transgender people in a positive light by showing that we are just like all other people. 
"For those asking: the doll is considered to be the first 'transgender' doll because it's based on an individual who is trans. 
"Of course it is still just a regular girl doll because that's exactly what I am: a regular girl!" Read More Transgender girl aged 11 shot with a BB gun by boy in school 
Jazz was first thrust into the public eye at the age of six when her parents allowed to her take part in a groundbreaking TV interview with Barbara Walters. 
She later shared her inspiring story in a YouTube channel, a picture book and TV series I Am Jazz, becoming one of the most high-profile advocates for the transgender community. Jazz said she hoped the doll would show transgender people in a positive light (Photo: Instagram/jazzjennings) 
Jazz has told how she "longed to be a girl” from as young as she can remember. 
She said: “Mum tells me that even as a two-year-old when she praised me for being a good boy, I’d correct her saying, ‘I’m a good girl.’ 
“When I was two, Mum says I asked when the fairy was going to come with a magic wand and take away my penis.” 
Her parents were supportive but she faced taunts at school. 
Jazz said: “At lunchtime some of the girls wouldn’t sit with me and some of the boys even called me ‘it’. When I got home I’d cry. 
“I wasn’t allowed to use the boys’ or girls’ toilets, I had to go to the nurse’s office to use the bathroom. I felt so isolated.” Jazz Jennings as a boy (Photo: PA Real Life Features) 
But she refused to let bullies get the better of her. 
“By the time I was 10, almost everyone in school knew I was transgender” she said. 
“I had a close group of girl friends who would stand by me, and the older I got, the more comfortable I became, so I tried not to let the bullies upset me.” Like us on Facebook
